steps.name: Remove tape on drogue parachute, shroud lines, and shock cord.

content.text: Restricting the parachute, shroud lines, and shock cord can result in the vehicle falling without any method to slow down, leading to a failed recovery.

steps.name: Verify the parachute, shroud lines, and shock cord are free of damage.

content.text: Damage constitutes tears, rips, stiffened areas, burns, or singes.

steps.name: Untangle parachute shroud lines

content.text: Improper storage of the drogue parachute shroud lines can result in the parachute failing to open fully after deployment. This could produce unexpectedly high descent velocities and lead to a failed recovery.

steps.name: Z-fold the parachute

content.text: Improper folding can result in the parachute failing to eject or open fully after deployment. This could produce unexpectedly high descent velocities and lead to a failed recovery.

steps.name: Wrap parachute with the small square of nomex

content.text: If Nomex does not fully cover the parachute, black powder combustion may burn holes in the parachute. This could produce unexpectedly high descent velocities and lead to a failed recovery

steps.name: Wrap the parachute in a rubber band to maintain shape.
Connect the parachute swivel to the nomex with a quick link.

content.text: If Nomex is not attached at the base of the shroud lines, it may lift up along the shroud lines and reef the parachute resulting in high descent velocities and a failed recovery.

steps.name: Verify that the drogue shock cord has a loop for parachute attachment.

content.text: The parachute should be connected roughly 2/3 along the shock cord from the forward end.

tokens.value: The parachute should be connected roughly 2/3 along the shock cord from the forward end.

content.text: Improperly attached quick link may result in the drogue parachute separating from the launch vehicle and cause failed recovery

steps.name: Cover the 3 ft closest to the avionics bay with a shock cord protector.

content.text: Nomex should cover the majority of the area to prevent black powder combustion from reaching parts of the parachute

steps.name: Apply duct tape to both ends of the shock cord protector.

content.text: If Nomex slips, the region holding the parachute may be exposed to black powder ccombustion

steps.name: Form bundles of shock cord every 12" along the length of the shock cord.

content.text: Secure bundles with masking tape. Ensure that the bundles are not too tight or sparse.
Bundles that are too tight will inhibit shock cord from fully expanding; bundles that are too sparse will not be effective in absorbing force

steps.name: Attach the drogue parachute to the shock cord.

content.text: This connection and others on the harness will be re-verified before flight.

steps.name: Attach a quick link to the forward end of the shock cord.
Attach a quick link to the aft end of the shock cord.
Set aside the completed parachute and recovery harness.
Remove tape on main parachute, shroud lines, and shock cord.

content.text: Restricting the main parachute, shroud lines, and shock cord can result in the vehicle falling without any method to slow down, leading to a failed recovery.

steps.name: Verify the parachute, shroud lines, and shock cord are free of damage.

content.text: Damage constitutes tears, rips, stiffened areas, burns, or singes.

steps.name: Untangle parachute shroud lines

content.text: Improper storage of the parachute shroud lines can result in the parachute failing to open fully after deployment. This could produce unexpectedly high descent velocities and lead to a failed recovery.

steps.name: Z-fold the parachute

content.text: Improper folding can result in the parachute failing to eject or open fully after deployment. This could produce unexpectedly high descent velocities and lead to a failed recovery.

steps.name: Wrap parachute with the small square of nomex

content.text: If Nomex does not fully cover the parachute, black powder combustion may burn holes in the parachute. This could produce unexpectedly high descent velocities and lead to a failed recovery

steps.name: Wrap the parachute in a rubber band to maintain shape.
Connect the parachute swivel to the nomex with a quick link.

content.text: If Nomex is not attached at the base of the shroud lines, it may lift up along the shroud lines and reef the parachute resulting in high descent velocities and a failed recovery.

steps.name: Verify that the drogue shock cord has a loop for parachute attachment.

content.text: The parachute should be connected roughly 2/3 along the shock cord from the forward end.
Improperly attached quick link may result in the drogue parachute separating from the launch vehicle and cause failed recovery

steps.name: Cover the 3 ft closest to the avionics bay with a shock cord protector.

content.text: Nomex should cover the majority of the area to prevent black powder combustion from reaching parts of the parachute

steps.name: Apply duct tape to both ends of the shock cord protector.

content.text: If Nomex slips, the region holding the parachute may be exposed to black powder ccombustion

steps.name: Form bundles of shock cord every 12" along the length of the shock cord.

content.text: Secure bundles with masking tape. Ensure that the bundles are not too tight or sparse.
Bundles that are too tight will inhibit shock cord from fully expanding; bundles that are too sparse will not be effective in absorbing force

steps.name: Attach the main parachute to the shock cord.

content.text: This connection and others on the harness will be re-verified before flight.

steps.name: Attach a quick link to the forward end of the shock cord.
Attach a quick link to the aft end of the shock cord.
Set aside the completed parachute and recovery harness.
Gather the following items:

content.text:
- 4x 6 mL plastic vials
- 4x E-matches
- Black Powder
- 1 cc measurement tool
- Cellulose insulation (dog barf)
- Tape
- Sharpie
- Antistatic bag

tokens.value:
- 4x 6 mL plastic vials
- 4x E-matches
- Black Powder
- 1 cc measurement tool
- Cellulose insulation (dog barf)
- Tape
- Sharpie
- Antistatic bag

steps.name: The following steps shall be done by the team mentor.
Construct a 3.5g charge and label it "MAIN -- PRIMARY"
Construct a 4.0g charge and label it "MAIN -- BACKUP"
Construct a 3.5g charge and label it "DROGUE -- PRIMARY"
Construct a 4.0g charge and label it "DROGUE -- BACKUP"
Place all charges in antistatic bag.
Charge LiPo battery.
Measure and record battery voltage
Power on STEMCRaFT capsule by removing the RBF tag
Power on team transceiver
Power on team LoRa radio
Initiate checkout sequence
Slide STEMCRaFT Capsule onto threaded rod.
Secure the bottom of the capsule with a 1/4-20 nut.
Something about cameras???
Slide the nose cone bulkhead onto the threaded rod.
Secure the nose cone bulkhead to the threaded rod
Verify the nose cone bulkhead is secured.
Set the STEMCRaFT Payload aside to await vehicle integration.
Charge LiPo battery completely
Measure and record the LiPo voltage
Power on ADS payload by removing RBF tag
Calibrate ADS payload
Power off ADS payload
Verify forward u-bolt is secured.
Verify aft stud is secured.
Verify forward and aft threaded nuts are secured.
Set the ADS payload aside to await vehicle integration.
Inspect fins and verify that they are undamaged and free of cracks.

content.text: In the event that a fin is damaged, replace the damaged fin with a spare.

steps.name: Slide each fin axially until the locator pins are in place.
Install the thrust plate on top of the fins so that the rear notches align using fin clamps
Attach the thrust plate to the four fins using 1/4-20'' x 0.5'' bolts
Verify the motor mount tube is secured in place.
Verify that the fins cannot move radially or axially.
Verify that the bolts holding the fin clamps in place are fully tightened
Verify that the rail buttons are fully tightened.
Verify that the following are free of cracks and unintended holes.

content.text:
- Airframe
- Couplers
- Bulkheads

steps.name: Sign-off for vehicle integrity.
Locate the following:

content.text:
- Nose cone subassembly
- Main parachute recovery harness
- Forward airframe

tokens.value:
- Nose cone subassembly
- Main parachute recovery harness
- Forward airframe

headers.name: Forward Nose Cone and Airframe Integration

steps.name: Pass the forward end of the recovery harness through the forward airframe.
Connect the forward end of the recovery harness to the nose cone bulkhead.
Verify the quick link is tight by checking with a teammate.
Slide the nose cone shoulder into the forward airframe.
Connect the nose cone to the forward airframe with 4x 4-40 shear pins.
Push the main parachute into the forward airframe.
Push the recovery harness into the forward airframe

content.text: Push in small sections to prevent tangling.

tokens.value: Push in small sections to prevent tangling.

steps.name: Insert 2x large handfuls of dog barf (cellulose insullation)
Cap off the forward airframe.
Locate the following:

content.text:
- Aft airframe
- Drogue parachute recovery harness
- ADS subassembly
- Booster subassembly

tokens.value:
- Aft airframe
- Drogue parachute recovery harness
- ADS subassembly
- Booster subassembly

headers.name: Aft Airframe, ADS, and Booster Integration

steps.name: Rotate the ADS mechanism to the clocked orientation.
Connect the ADS coupler to the booster airframe with 4x 4-40 shear pins.
Pass the aft end of the recovery harness through the aft airframe front to back.
Connect the recovery harness to the ADS forward bulkhead.
Verify the quick link is tight by checking with a teammate.
Slide the ADS forward coupler into the aft airframe.
Connect the aft airframe to the ADS coupler with 4x 4-40 shear pins.
Push the recovery harness into the aft airframe.
Push the drogue parachute into the aft airframe.
Push the remaining recovery harness into the aft airframe.
Insert 2x large handfuls of dog barf (cellulose insullation)
Cap off the aft airframe.
Sign-off for vehicle readiness.
Connect jumper wires to 4x e-match passthroughs on the avionics stack.
Place the avionics stack in a vertical flight-like configuration.
Power on the backup computer.
Verify 3x beeps to indicate nominal continuity.
Power off the backup computer.
Power on the primary computer.
Verify 3x beeps to indicate nominal continuity.
Verify signal acquisition by TeleBT ground station.
Power off primary computer.
Remove 4x jumper wires.
Gather the following:

content.text:
- Forward vehicle subassembly
- Avionics stack
- 4x black powder charges
- Aft vehicle subassembly

tokens.value:
- Forward vehicle subassembly
- Avionics stack
- 4x black powder charges
- Aft vehicle subassembly

steps.name: The following steps shall be done by the team mentor.

content.text: The following steps involve black powder explosives and shall only be completed by the team mentor.

tokens.value: The following steps involve black powder explosives and shall only be completed by the team mentor.

steps.name: Verify the team mentor and all team members are wearing safety glasses.
Uncap the forward airframe.
Connect the main recovery harness to the forward avionics bulkhead.
Verify the quick link is tight by checking with a friend.
Connect the "MAIN -- PRIMARY" charge to the correct terminal.
Connect the "MAIN -- BACKUP" charge to the correct terminal.
Slide the forward airframe onto the forward avionics coupler.
Connect the sections with 4x 10-32 rivets.
Uncap the aft airframe.
Connect the main recovery harness to the forward avionics bulkhead.
Verify the quick link is tight by checking with a friend.
Connect the "DROGUE -- PRIMARY" charge to the correct terminal.
Connect the "DROGUE -- BACKUP" charge to the correct terminal.
Slide the avionics coupler into the aft airframe.
Connect the sections with 4x 10-32 rivets.
Remove motor retainer.
Slide motor until forward closer contacts ADS stud.
Rotate motor casing clockwise until aft closure bottoms out on retainer.
Fasten the motor retainer.
Verify the motor retainer is tight by checking with a friend.
Fill out flight card and give it to the PM.
Sign-off for flight readiness.

content.text: Go flight. Go NUSTARS.

steps.name: Place the launch rail in a horizontal position.
Slide the vehicle onto the launch rail.

content.text: One person should coordinate the effort. Bending or twisting the vehicle while constrained to the rail can damage the rial buttons.

steps.name: Raise the rail to vertical and verify that it is locked.
Arm the backup altimeter.
Verify three continuity beeps from the backup altimeter.
Arm the primary altimeter.
Verify 3x beeps from the primary altimeter.

content.text: There should be a total of six beeps. Two distinct tones in sets of three.

tokens.value: There should be a total of six beeps. Two distinct tones in sets of three.

steps.name: Verify signal acquisition from primary altimeter ground station.
Remove the motor cap.
Insert the igniter into the motor.
Re-attach motor cap to hold the igniter in place.
Touch alligator clips to check for stray current.
Connect alligator clips to the igniter wires.
Check igniter for continuity.

content.text: Clear all personnel away from the pad. Continuity checks have the potential to prematurely fire the rocket motor.

steps.name: Clear the pad area and await RSO and LCO launch approval.
Launch.
Need steps for troubleshooting maybe as separate procedures.

content.text: MISSING STEPS

steps.name: Locate the vehicle using visual cues or the GPS locator.
Check surroundings around vehicle to ensure no part has landed in a hazardous environment

content.text: Hazardous environments include power lines, trees, or water.

steps.name: Take ample photos of every section of the vehicle.
Disarm both altimeters.
Access any encloses charge locations and verify detonation of all charges.
Record observed damage to the vehicle and recovery system.
Disconnect the primary and drogue recovery harnesses.
Disconnect and bundle the primary and drogue parachutes.
Transport all sections of the vehicle back to base.
Disconnect all vehicle sections and recovery harness hardware.
Clean the inside of the vehicle airframes using isopropyl alcohol.
Disassemble the avionics bay and remove ungrounded electrical connections.
Clean the avionics bay bulkheads using isopropyl alcohol.
Clean the outside of the vehicle with a damp cloth.

content.text: Isopropyl alcohol will degrade paint if present on the vehicle.

I think the imu needs recalibration every time it turns off?
that's what I thought but iw as waiting for clarification on how that calibration would work from electrical
Procedurally that is gonna be a nightmare. Do you think we can avoid it? I just worry about the 3+ hour delay between turning stuff on and actually flying (speaking from experience last year)

release_note.text: Preliminary draft. On my end, I need to add more steps relating to troubleshooting + caution/warning tags. For electrical and mechanical, please review what I have right now and leave comments accordingly. For more fleshed out procedural changes, slack me and I'll put it in this form.
